description: Dive into "Castles of Enchantment: Discover Seville's Fortresses" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Castles of Enchantment: Discover Seville's Fortresses

sources.snippet: Built on a hill overlooking the town of Castle of Alcala de Guadaira, El Castillo De Alcal√° De Guada√≠ra was built by the Moors during the 12th and 13th centuries. Despite being abandoned for two centuries, restoration work on the castle began in 1998, restoring it to its Medieval splendor. Now‚Äôs on the list with some of the best castles in Andalucia.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Castles in Andalucia Worth Visiting

places.name: Castillo de Alcal√° de Guada√≠ra

reviews.text: Firstly, I'm reviewing the town, not just the castle. This is a delightful place. Much bigger than the initial impression but also still has an intimate feeling. It's close enough to Seville to day trip but also has great tapas bars (Buenos Aires, my favourite). The Castillo is attractive and free to enter and there's a striking church above. Both sunset and sunrise are striking from this vantage point. Come and explore.... Check out the dragon bridge and the park below.
Awesome structure. This is a free look at castle ruins not much else. Great views with rebuilt walkways for you to walk around the walls. Some stairways are very steep and narrow.
Lovely place, definitely visit if you are there! You can have a nice view to the city and to the neighbourhood.

places.address: Av. del √Åguila, s/n, 41500 Alcal√° de Guada√≠ra, Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Royal Alc√°zar of Seville is a landmark Moorish royal palace featuring fountain-filled gardens, ornate arches, and 16th-century tiles. It is considered one of the finest examples of Mudejar architecture in Spain, showcasing a blend of Moorish and Renaissance styles. The palace complex has a rich history dating back to the 10th century when it was initially built as a Moorish fortress.

sources.snippet: Royal Palace is a UNESCO-listed architectural treasure that recalls Seville‚Äôs Arab influences and has since been reconstructed in the successors‚Äô architectural styles, making it one of Spain‚Äôs most diversified and unusual architectural monuments. You‚Äôll see azulejos and horseshoe arches everywhere, as well as floral decorative patterns, mosaics, tapestries, and Renaissance finishes. Visitors appreciate this well-known tourist site for its stunning gardens full of blooming trees and plants.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Castles in Andalucia Worth Visiting

sources.snippet: The Alc√°zar of Seville was used as a location for the hugely successful HBO TV series, Game of Thrones. The palace stood in for the Water Gardens of Dorne in various scenes in four episodes of Season Five and one of Season Six. The private estate is owned by Prince Dorian Martell, the wheelchair-bound head of House Martell and ruler of Dorne.
sources.shortName: Game of Thrones locations | Alcazar | Seville

sources.snippet: Royal Alc√°zar of Seville ‚Äì a royal palace in Seville has to be the crown jewel of the city. And quite literally, because it was built as a house for kings and still is the house of kings ‚Äì the upper floors of Alc√°zar still host the royal family when they visit Seville!
sources.shortName: 17 most beautiful castles and palaces in Andalusia, Spain

places.name: Royal Alc√°zar of Seville

reviews.text:
The Real Alc√°zar of Seville is an exceptional place - we absolutely loved it!
The site is very large, and we visited in April when everything was green and in full bloom. It was truly beautiful.

We highly recommend wearing comfortable shoes, as there's a lot of walking involved. Don't forget to bring water and take your time - there are plenty of perfect spots for photos and relaxing strolls.

It's essential to buy tickets well in advance. We purchased ours two weeks before our visit and could only get the last available time slot. After booking, you have to wait for a confirmation email.

Make sure to get your tickets long before your trip, as entrance is strictly based on the time stated on your ticket - no early entries were allowed for anyone.
We didn't had a guide and were able to enjoy the garden.

To fully enjoy the visit, it's a good idea to prepare children ahead of time and let them know there will be quite a bit of walking involved üòÑüëç

Royal Alc√°zar of Seville is one of the key landmarks when visiting Seville.  We went over the August Bank holiday weekend and it was BUSY - as you'd expect, not to mention incredibly hot, both inside and out.  Take a fan and plenty of water as the place is large!  There is a cafe but we didn't use it.  There seems to be a lot of recommendations about booking in advance, but we booked at about 10pm on Saturday night and got tickets for 11.30 the next morning.  Maybe we were lucky or August is quieter... I don't know.  Book to be on the safe side - I'd recommend using a local operator if poss - prices range from ¬£50 each to ¬£17pp which we opted for!  That said, this didn't include a tour / audio. There were QR codes but didn't try those.  Nothing is in English either - just an observation.  Inside, the palace consisted of a series of interconnected rooms, mainly empty (no furniture) with the exception of beautiful mosaic floors, ceilings, walls, tapestries and plaster work, open courtyards, you get the idea.  Gardens were gorgeous.  Evidently, you can see the Royal bedrooms but have to book far in advance of your visit.

A magnificent and very beautiful palace, as if you were in a medieval museum, a mixture of Western and Eastern civilizations, Christianity and Islam, a mixture of green nature and beautiful human heritage. Visiting it with the cathedral is definitely worth the trip.
